See G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and is within the jurisdictional limits of the Massachusetts Superior Court.

See G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County because the events giving rise to Plaintiff’s claims occurred in Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business within Norfolk County.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the traditional distinction between licensees and invitees and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers to lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage specifically criticizes status-based classifications and does not characterize the plaintiff as a ‘business invitee’ or limit the duty to such a category. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that plaintiff was a business invitee or that the duty arises specifically from invitee status; instead it supports a broader reasonable-care duty to all lawful entrants.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places."

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was a business invitee to whom Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises, including maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers of which the landowner knows or should know. Although this plaintiff was a residential tenant rather than a commercial invitee, the quoted rule of duty to “all persons lawfully on the premises” encompasses business invitees, and the court’s articulation of the duty matches the proposition’s description of the standard of care owed.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Alternatively, and/or in addition, Defendant, through its employees, had constructive notice of the hazardous condition because the puddle existed for a sufficient period of time and was in a high-traffic area where reasonable inspection would have discovered it.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that defendant had constructive notice because the puddle existed for a sufficient time and in a high‑traffic area where reasonable inspection would have discovered it. Oliveri discusses when circumstantial evidence (including location and employee proximity) can establish the time element and constructive notice, but in this case the court holds that the evidence was insufficient and orders a directed verdict for the defendant. Thus, Oliveri is authority limiting, not supporting, a finding of constructive notice under similar facts.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it.… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to make reasonable inspections of the Premises and to remedy or warn of any unreasonably dangerous conditions, including liquid or ice on floors in customer walkways.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The court adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and the mode-of-operation doctrine, expressly stating that a store owner must maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, including taking reasonable steps to prevent and remedy foreseeable dangerous conditions such as produce on the floor. The opinion explains that the owner’s duty is to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees against such dangers, which encompasses reasonable inspection and remedial measures or warnings regarding hazards like liquid or produce debris on customer walkways.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: “A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees… and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.” … “[T]he keeper of a grocery store may be liable to a customer who slips on produce that is on the floor because of the storekeeper’s negligent marketing and display thereof.”

See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres D.raw_text: See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sch., Inc.*, 408 Mass. 393 (1990).
See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres D.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and servants under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres D.case_name: Worcester Insurance v. Fells Acres Day School, Inc.
See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres D.support_reasoning: The court discusses vicarious liability and respondeat superior but holds that, on the stipulated facts, the intentional sexual assaults were outside the scope of employment and thus do not trigger vicarious liability for Fells Acres. The opinion therefore rejects, rather than affirms, that the defendant school is vicariously liable for its employees’ negligent/intentional acts in this context. It is not proper authority for the general proposition that a defendant is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees under respondeat superior.
See *Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres D.relevant_excerpt: “An employer may be held vicariously liable for the intentional tort of an agent if the tortious act or acts were committed within the scope of employment. … Under this standard, the conduct alleged here does not trigger vicarious liability. … On the basis of the stipulated facts, then, Fells Acres is not vicariously liable for the assaults and batteries.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s breach of its duty of care was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s slip, fall, and resulting injuries.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a homeowner owed a duty of reasonable care in the storage of firearms and thus whether a negligence claim could proceed at all; the court explicitly reserves issues of breach and causation for the jury. The opinion does not decide that any defendant’s breach was a direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injury and in fact states that questions of breach, damages, and causal relation are for the jury. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a defendant’s breach was a direct and proximate cause of a slip-and-fall injury.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions — whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendant’s breach and the damage were causally related — to be the special province of the jury.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Any contention that the puddle was “open and obvious” is without merit under the circumstances because (a) the shiny tile appearance could reasonably obscure the presence of water; and (b) even where a danger is open and obvious, a landowner may remain liable where it should anticipate that visitors will encounter the condition despite its obviousness.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses the open-and-obvious doctrine in the context of snow and ice and expressly states that even if such conditions are open and obvious, a property owner may still have a duty where it should anticipate that visitors will proceed despite the risk. While the facts involve outdoor ice rather than indoor shiny tile obscuring water, the second part of the proposition—continued liability despite obviousness—is directly supported by the court’s reasoning adopting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A. The opinion does not discuss shiny tile obscuring water, but it clearly endorses the broader legal principle that open and obvious dangers do not automatically eliminate the landowner’s duty.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “A property owner, however, is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where it ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 338 (2010), quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A comment f, at 220 (1965). … Therefore, even if snow and ice were properly viewed as an open and obvious danger, this fact alone will not always relieve a property owner of the duty to use reasonable care….”}

*Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Thurlow v. Shaw’s Supermarkets, Inc.*, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 175 (2000)
*Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care applicable to reasonable restaurant operators and premises owners under Massachusetts law.
*Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies Massachusetts premises liability standards to a supermarket’s operation of a fish display and finds that Shaw’s conduct was negligent for failing to keep the area reasonably safe and for having constructive notice of a hazardous water accumulation. This is squarely about the standard of care for reasonable premises owners and operators of food display areas, and the court affirms a finding that Shaw’s fell below that standard. Thus, it supports the proposition that a defendant restaurant or similar food premises operator can be found negligent under Massachusetts law when it fails to address such hazards.
*Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “One who controls business premises has an obligation ‘to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition…’ … The judge found… that ‘the extended ice case was filled by hand and at times, simply the process of customers picking up the items displayed, would occasionally spill some amounts of ice onto the floor.’ … [T]he judge concluded that the defendant had constructive notice of the hazard…. [W]e are not prepared to say that the judge’s finding that ‘someone at Shaw’s reasonably should have been aware of this amount of water on the floor…’ is plainly wrong.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care applicable to reasonable restaurant operators and premises owners under Massachusetts law.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses the standard of care for a store owner toward business visitors under Massachusetts law and upholds a jury verdict finding negligence. The court explains that premises owners must keep the premises reasonably safe, are not insurers, but can be found negligent if a dangerous condition exists long enough that they should have discovered and remedied it. By holding that the evidence was sufficient for a jury to find that Stop & Shop failed to meet this standard, the opinion supports the proposition that defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care applicable to reasonable premises/restaurant operators.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, "The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action." ... We think that it could be found, however, that the presence of this ice cream on the floor and vestibule of the defendant’s store constituted an appreciable danger to customers.

*Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Ma.raw_text: *Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Mass. 497, 501 (1967).
*Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Ma.case_name: Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.
*Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses duty and the availability of a negligence claim for pecuniary loss in the absence of privity, not causation of personal injuries. The court holds there was sufficient evidence of negligent staking to go to trial, but does not discuss or decide whether the defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing the plaintiff’s injuries; instead, it focuses on the existence of a duty and the permissibility of recovery for economic loss. Thus, it does not support the specific causation proposition stated.
*Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.*, 351 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The principal respects in which there was evidence tending to prove negligent placing of stakes are these. Two catchbasins were designated by the defendant’s employees in wrong locations and had to be rebuilt by the plaintiff. Rogers Road was staked out eight feet away from its proper location, necessitating the rebuilding of the road once the error was discovered… Accordingly, we hold that it was error to direct a verdict for the defendant on count 2.”

*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other general and special damages recognized under Massachusetts law.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about evidentiary issues, jury instructions, income tax instructions, and excessiveness of a verdict, not a general statement of the full range of recoverable tort damages. However, the court does expressly approve jury instructions allowing recovery for impaired future earning capacity and affirms a substantial verdict that clearly includes pain and suffering, future loss of earning capacity, and other general damages. Thus, it indirectly supports the proposition that a plaintiff may recover fair and reasonable compensation for injuries and losses (including future earning capacity and pain and suffering) proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence under Massachusetts law, but it is not a comprehensive articulation of all listed damage categories.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.relevant_excerpt: "The judge instructed the jury that the plaintiff was ‘entitled to her past and future impaired earning capacity.’ ... The evidence warranted an inference that the plaintiff’s loss of function would increase in the future, and that her earning capacity would be diminished. ... There was evidence to support a finding that there would be substantial loss of earning capacity in the future. More important, there was evidence of enormous pain and suffering, which will persist over the plaintiff’s estimated remaining life span..."

Under G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any comparative negligence, if any, attributed to Plaintiff is less than the negligence of Defendant, and Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover his damages, reduced only by any percentage of negligence attributed to him, if any.

including prejudgment interest under G.L.raw_text: including prejudgment interest under G.L. c. 231, § 6B.
including prejudgment interest under G.L.proposition: Plaintiff seeks compensation for all such damages in an amount to be determined by the trier of fact, together with interest and costs as provided by law, including prejudgment interest under G.L. c. 231, § 6B.
